facts.text: Appeal preferred by the State of Bihar against High Court judgment allowing respondent's application under section 23 of Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931

anchor.surface_text: MAHAJAN J.--This appeal has been preferred by the State of Bihar against the judgment of a Special Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Patna allowing the application of the respondent under section 23 of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers Act, XXIII of 1931.

facts.text: Respondent was the keeper at all relevant times of the Bharati Press at Purulia

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was the keeper at all relevant times of the Bharati Press at Purulia, A pamphlet under the heading Sangram was printed at the said press and is alleged to have been circulated

facts.text: Pamphlet under heading 'Sangram' printed at Bharati Press and alleged to have been circulated in Purulia, district of Manbhum

anchor.surface_text: A pamphlet under the heading Sangram was printed at the said press and is alleged to have been circulated in the town of Purulia in the district of Manbhum. The Government of Bihar companysidered that the pamphlet

facts.text: Government of Bihar considered pamphlet contained objectionable matter under section 4(1) of Indian Press Emergency Powers Act

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bihar companysidered that the pamphlet companytained objectionable matter of the nature described under section 4  1  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act and required the press to furnish security

facts.text: Government required press to furnish security of Rs. 2,000 under section 3(3) by 19th September 1949

anchor.surface_text: of the Act and required the press to furnish security in the sum of Rs. 2,000, under section 3 3  of the Act by the 19th September, 1949. On the 26th September, 1949, the respondent applied to the High Court

facts.text: Respondent applied to High Court under section 23 on 26th September 1949 to set aside the order

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th September, 1949, the respondent applied to the High Court under section 23 for setting aside the above order. This application was allowed by the majority of the Judges companystituting the Bench.

facts.text: High Court allowed the application by majority (Ramaswami and Sarjoo Prosad JJ.); Shearer J. dissented

anchor.surface_text: This application was allowed by the majority of the Judges companystituting the Bench. Shearer J. was of the view that the application should be dismissed. Several objections were raised to the validity

facts.text: Supreme Court holds section 4(1)(a) within Article 19(2) as it deals with incitement to murder or cognizable offences involving violence undermining security of State

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that speeches or expressions on the part of an individual which incite to or encourage the companymission of violent crimes, such as murder, cannot but be matters which would undermine the security of the State and companye within the ambit of a law sanctioned by article. 19 2  of the Constitution.

precedents.citation: Romesh Thapar The State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Romesh Thapar The State of Madras 1 , and Brij Bhushan V. The State of Delhi 2 , found, though with some reluctance, that section 4 1   a  of the Act was repugnant to the Constitution and therefore void.

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 9(1-A) of Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act authorizing restrictions for public safety or maintenance of public order is void under Article 19(2)
precedents.cited_holding: unless a law restricting freedom of speech and expression is directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it, such law cannot fall within the reservation under clause 2 of article 19

precedents.citation: Brij Bhushan V. The State of Delhi 2

anchor.surface_text: Brij Bhushan V. The State of Delhi 2 , found, though with some reluctance, that section 4 1   a  of the Act was repugnant to the Constitution and therefore void. Mr. Justice Shearer, however, held that the pamphlet was a seditious libel

precedents.case_name: Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Pre-censorship provisions for maintenance of public order are void under Article 19(1)(a) read with Article 19(2)

precedents.citation: Bhagwati Charan Shukla v. Government of C.P. Berar 1

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwati Charan Shukla v. Government of C.P. Berar 1 , that though the pamphlet in question uses extravagant language and there is in it the usual crude emotional appeal which is the stock-in-trade of the demagogue as well as a blundering and ineffective attempt to ape the poets, that is all,

precedents.case_name: Bhagwati Charan Shukla v. Government of C.P. Berar
precedents.cited_proposition: Writings using extravagant language, crude emotional appeal, and attempt to ape poets do not incite to violence or crimes
precedents.cited_holding: though the pamphlet in question uses extravagant language and there is in it the usual crude emotional appeal which is the stock-in-trade of the demagogue as well as a blundering and ineffective attempt to ape the poets, that is all, and there is nothing more in it

precedents.citation: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Govermnent 2

anchor.surface_text: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Govermnent 2 . The learned Chief Justice therein held that in order to show that certain words fall under section 4 1   a  it is not necessary to show that the words tend to incite or to encourage the commission of a particular offence or offences

precedents.case_name: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Government
precedents.cited_proposition: To fall under section 4(1)(a), words need not tend to incite a particular offence but cognizable offences involving violence in general
precedents.cited_holding: it is not necessary to show that the words tend to incite or to encourage the commission of a particular offence or offences and that it is sufficient if they tend to incite to or to encourage the commission of cognizable offences of violence in general
